review.title: A Novel Neural Network Model for Joint POS Tagging and Graph-based Dependency Parsing
review.abstract: We present a novel neural network model that learns POS tagging and graph-based dependency parsing jointly. Our model uses bidirectional LSTMs to learn feature representations shared for both POS tagging and dependency parsing tasks, thus handling the feature-engineering problem. Our extensive experiments, on 19 languages from the Universal Dependencies project, show that our model outperforms the state-of-the-art neural network-based Stack-propagation model for joint POS tagging and transition-based dependency parsing, resulting in a new state of the art. Our code is open-source and available at:
histories: v2: also include universal POS tagging, UAS and LAS accuracies w.r.t gold-standard segmentation on Universal Dependencies 2.0 - CoNLL 2017 shared task test data; in CoNLL 2017

metadata.title: A Novel Neural Network Model for Joint POS Tagging and Graph-based Dependency Parsing

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Over the past decade, the issue of dependence has become a central research topic in the NLP, reinforced by the success of CoNLL 2006 and 2007, which jointly analyze tasks of multilingual dependence (Buchholz and Marsi, 2006; Nivre et al., 2007a). McDonald and Nivre (2011) identify two types of data-driven methods for dependence: graph-based approaches (Eisner, 1996; McDonald et al., 2005; Koo and Collins, 2010) and transition-based approaches (Yamada and Matsumoto, 2003). Most traditional graphics or transition-based parsing approaches manually define a set of core and combined traits associated with hot representation (McDonald and Pereira, 2006; Bohnet, 2010; Zhang and Nivre, Nivre, Nivre, Nivre, 2011; Ballevre et al., 2013; Choi and McCallum, 2013; Recent work shows that learning is deeply dependent in dependency.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Experimental setup
sections.text: According to Zhang and Weiss (2016) and Plank et al. (2016), we are conducting multilingual experiments with 19 languages from the Universal Dependencies (UD) Treebanks1 v1.2, using the universal POS tagset (Petrov et al., 2012) instead of the language-specific POS tagset.2 For dependency parsing, the rating size is the marked attachment score (LAS).The LAS score is the percentage of words to which both dependency arc and relationship type are correctly assigned.

sections.heading: 3.2 Implementation details
sections.text: Our jPTDP is implemented with DYNET v2.0 (Neubig et al., 2017). • 3 We optimize the objective function with Adam (Kingma and Ba, 2014) using standard DYNET parameter settings and without mini-batches. We use a specified random seed, and we do not use pre-trained embedding in any experiment. According to Kiperwasser and Goldberg (2016b) and Plank et al. (2016), we apply a word failure rate of 0.25 and gauss noise with σ = 0.2 after each training period. For the training, we run for 30 epochs and evaluate the mixed accuracy of the correct assignment of POS tag along with dependency sheet and relationship type to the development epoch. We perform a minimal grid search of hyper parameters in English. We find that the highest mixed accuracy on the English development parameters 2016 consists of ZPTDP (if we include word parameters 128-12hi-1dimension.org).

sections.heading: 3.3 Main results
sections.text: Table 1 compares the POS marking and dependence on the results of our model jPTDP with results obtained in previous work using the same experimental setup.In terms of POS marking, our common model jPTDP generally achieves similar POS marking accuracies as the SOTA-BiLSTM aux model (Plank et al., 2016).Our model also achieves a higher average POS marking accuracy than the SOTA common model stack propagation (Zhang and White, 2016).Note that there are slightly higher marking results than English, it took 6 hours for training with these hyperparameters, and then you get a speed of 700 words / second, which are evaluated on a 2.2 GHz Core i7 processor.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we describe our novel model for joint POS tagging and graph-based dependency parsing using bidirectional LSTM-based feature representations. Multilingual experiments show that our model is state-of-the-art in both POS tagging and dependency parsing. Our code is open source and, together with pre-trained models, is available at: https: / / github.com / datquocnguyen / jPTDP.Acknowledgments: The first author is supported by an International Postgraduate Research Scholarship - a grant from the Australian Government Research Training Program - and a NICTA NRPA Top-Up Scholarship.

Some attempts have been conducted to avoid using POS tags during dependency parsing (Dyer et al., 2015; Ballesteros et al., 2015), however, these approaches still additionally use the automatic POS tags to achieve the best accuracy.

Some attempts have been conducted to avoid using POS tags during dependency parsing (Dyer et al., 2015; Ballesteros et al., 2015), however, these approaches still additionally use the automatic POS tags to achieve the best accuracy.

Alternatively, joint learning both POS tagging and dependency parsing has gained more attention because: i) more accurate POS tags could lead to improved parsing performance and ii) the the syntactic context of a parse tree could help resolve POS ambiguities (Hatori et al., 2011; Li et al., 2011; Bohnet and Nivre, 2012; Qian and Liu, 2012; Wang and Xue, 2014; Zhang et al., 2015; Alberti et al., 2015; Johannsen et al., 2016; Zhang and Weiss, 2016).

POS tagging: Using shared BiLSTM-based feature vectors, then we follow a common approach to compute the cross-entropy objective loss LPOS(t̂, t), in which t̂ and t are the sequence of predicted POS tags and sequence of gold POS tags of words in the input sentence s, respectively (Goldberg, 2016; Plank et al., 2016).

An arc-factored parsing approach learns the scores of the arcs in a graph (Kübler et al., 2009).
Then, using an efficient decoding algorithm such as Eisner (1996)’s algorithm, we can find a maximum spanning tree—the highest scoring parse tree—of the graph from those arc scores:
Following Kiperwasser and Goldberg (2016b), we score an arc by using a MLP with one-node output layer

We now compute a marginbased hinge loss Larc with loss-augmented inference to maximize the margin between the gold unlabeled parse tree and the highest scoring incorrect tree (Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016b).

Discussion: Prior neural network-based joint models for POS tagging and dependency parsing are feed-forward network- and transition-based approaches (Alberti et al., 2015; Zhang and Weiss, 2016), while our model is BiLSTM- and graphbased method.

Discussion: Prior neural network-based joint models for POS tagging and dependency parsing are feed-forward network- and transition-based approaches (Alberti et al., 2015; Zhang and Weiss, 2016), while our model is BiLSTM- and graphbased method.

Discussion: Prior neural network-based joint models for POS tagging and dependency parsing are feed-forward network- and transition-based approaches (Alberti et al., 2015; Zhang and Weiss, 2016), while our model is BiLSTM- and graphbased method. Our model can be considered as a two-component mixture of a tagging component and a parsing component. Here, the tagging component can be viewed as a simplified version without the additional auxiliary loss for rare words of the BiLSTM-based POS tagging model proposed by Plank et al. (2016). The parsing component can be viewed as an extension of the graph-based dependency model proposed by Kiperwasser and Goldberg (2016b), where we replace the input POS tag embeddings by the character-based representations of words.

Discussion: Prior neural network-based joint models for POS tagging and dependency parsing are feed-forward network- and transition-based approaches (Alberti et al., 2015; Zhang and Weiss, 2016), while our model is BiLSTM- and graphbased method. Our model can be considered as a two-component mixture of a tagging component and a parsing component. Here, the tagging component can be viewed as a simplified version without the additional auxiliary loss for rare words of the BiLSTM-based POS tagging model proposed by Plank et al. (2016). The parsing component can be viewed as an extension of the graph-based dependency model proposed by Kiperwasser and Goldberg (2016b), where we replace the input POS tag embeddings by the character-based representations of words.

TnT denotes the second order HMM-based TnT tagger (Brants, 2000).
BiLSTM-aux refers to the state-of-the-art (SOTA) BiLSTM-based POS tagging model with an additional auxiliary loss for rare words (Plank et al., 2016).
Stack-prop refers to the SOTA Stack-propagation model for joint POS tagging and transition-based dependency parsing (Zhang and Weiss, 2016).
B’15 denotes the character-based stack LSTM model for transition-based dependency parsing (Ballesteros et al., 2015).

TnT denotes the second order HMM-based TnT tagger (Brants, 2000). CRF denotes the Conditional random fields-based tagger, presented in Plank et al. (2014). Note that the (old) language code for Hebrew “iw” is referred to as “he” as in Plank et al. (2016). [⊕]: Results are reported in Plank et al. (2016). Stack-prop refers to the SOTA Stack-propagation model for joint POS tagging and transition-based dependency parsing (Zhang and Weiss, 2016).

PipelinePtag refers to a greedy version of the approach proposed by Alberti et al. (2015). RBGParser refers to the SOTA graph-based dependency parser with tensor decomposition, presented in Lei et al.

PipelinePtag refers to a greedy version of the approach proposed by Alberti et al. (2015). RBGParser refers to the SOTA graph-based dependency parser with tensor decomposition, presented in Lei et al. (2014). [*]: Results are reported in Zhang and Weiss (2016).

Regarding POS tagging, our joint model jPTDP generally obtains similar POS tagging accuracies to the SOTA BiLSTM-aux model (Plank et al., 2016).
Our model also achieves higher averaged POS tagging accuracy than the SOTA joint model Stack-propagation (Zhang and Weiss, 2016).

metadata.abstractText: We present a novel neural network model that learns POS tagging and graph-based dependency parsing jointly. Our model uses bidirectional LSTMs to learn feature representations shared for both POS tagging and dependency parsing tasks, thus handling the feature-engineering problem. Our extensive experiments, on 19 languages from the Universal Dependencies project, show that our model outperforms the state-of-the-art neural networkbased Stack-propagation model for joint POS tagging and transition-based dependency parsing, resulting in a new state of the art. Our code is open-source and available at: https://github.com/ datquocnguyen/jPTDP.
